title: War Against Midian
shortSummary: Numbers 31 recounts the Lord's command to Moses to take vengeance on the Midianites for leading Israel into sin. The chapter details the military campaign, the destruction of the Midianite men, the treatment of captives and spoils, and the subsequent purification and division of the booty according to God's instructions. This chapter highlights God's justice, holiness, and the importance of obedience to His commands.
timeline: c. 1445 BC - The Wilderness Wanderings after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who receives God's command and directs the military action against Midian.

keyCharacters.name: Phinehas
keyCharacters.description: Son of Eleazar the priest, who accompanies the army with the holy instruments and trumpets.

keyCharacters.name: Eleazar
keyCharacters.description: The priest who oversees the purification rites and the distribution of the spoils.

keyCharacters.name: Balaam
keyCharacters.description: A prophet killed in the battle, previously known for advising Midian to lead Israel into sin.

definitions.definition: A portion of the spoils or offerings lifted up and given to the Lord, symbolizing consecration and dedication.
Ceremonial cleansing required after contact with death or war to restore ritual cleanliness before reentering the camp.
Women and children taken alive after battle, some of whom were kept alive according to specific divine instructions.
A tax or portion taken from spoils or possessions to be given to God or His servants as an act of worship and obedience.

outline.heading: God Commands Vengeance on Midian
outline.description: God instructs Moses to take revenge on the Midianites for their role in leading Israel into sin, and Moses organizes a military force of 12,000 men, a thousand from each tribe.

outline.heading: The Battle and Defeat of Midian
outline.description: The Israelite army, led by Phinehas, attacks and kills all Midianite men, including their kings and Balaam, capturing women, children, and livestock, and burning their cities.

outline.heading: Moses' Judgment on the Captives and Purification Laws
outline.description: Moses rebukes the officers for sparing women who caused Israel to sin, commands the killing of certain captives, and instructs purification rituals for the soldiers and spoils.

outline.heading: Division of the Spoils and Tribute to the Lord
outline.description: The spoils are counted, divided between the warriors and the congregation, with a portion given as a tribute to the Lord and to the Levites who serve in the tabernacle.

outline.heading: Offering of Gold and Memorial
outline.description: The military leaders present an offering of gold as atonement, which Moses and Eleazar dedicate in the tabernacle as a memorial before the Lord.

application: Obedience to God's commands is essential, even when difficult, as God’s justice and holiness must be upheld.
Christians should seek purity and cleansing from sin, recognizing the need for spiritual purification after encountering death or defilement.
God requires a heart of worship expressed through giving back to Him a portion of what He has blessed us with.
Trust in God's righteous judgment and His sovereign plan, knowing He works through His people to accomplish His purposes.

keyVerses.text: Avenge the children of Israel of the Midianites: afterward shalt thou be gathered unto thy people.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's command for justice and foreshadows Moses' death, emphasizing obedience to divine instruction.

keyVerses.text: Behold, these caused the children of Israel, through the counsel of Balaam, to commit trespass against the LORD in the matter of Peor, and there was a plague among the congregation of the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: It explains the reason for God's judgment on Midian, highlighting the consequences of leading God's people into sin.

keyVerses.text: And do ye abide without the camp seven days: whosoever hath killed any person, and whosoever hath touched any slain, purify both yourselves and your captives on the third day, and on the seventh day.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the importance of ceremonial purification to maintain holiness before God.

keyVerses.text: We have therefore brought an oblation for the LORD, what every man hath gotten, of jewels of gold, chains, and bracelets, rings, earrings, and tablets, to make an atonement for our souls before the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: It shows the warriors’ recognition of God's sovereignty and their desire for atonement through giving offerings.
